description: Whales are large marine mammals occupying diverse niches from baleen filter feeders to toothed predators.
They undertake long migrations and feed on krill, fish or other marine animals depending on species.
Wolves are social canids that hunt cooperatively in packs and are key predators in many ecosystems.
They prey on ungulates and smaller mammals.
Walruses are large pinnipeds with tusks and whiskers that inhabit Arctic seas, feeding on benthic invertebrates.
They haul out on ice or beaches to rest and breed.
Wombats are burrowing marsupials native to Australia with stocky bodies and strong claws for digging.
They feed on grasses and roots and are mainly nocturnal.
Weasels are small carnivorous mammals with elongated bodies and short legs, adept at hunting small vertebrates.
They inhabit diverse habitats including woodlands and grasslands.
This is the largest animal known to have ever existed, reaching lengths of up to 100 feet and a weight of up to 200 tons.
These marine mammals are found in oceans worldwide and primarily feed on tiny shrimp-like animals called krill.
Despite their massive size, these animals are known for their gentle nature and are often observed breaching and tail-slapping.
